instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the related study to classify the mildew grade of sunflower seeds?

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the classification models in the related study to classify the mildew grade of sunflower seeds, and how accurate were the predictions?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the classification models in the related study was prediction accuracy. The accuracy of the predictions varied depending on the model used. instruction: How does the 1D-CNN model compare to the conventional machine learning algorithms in classifying the mildew grade of sunflower seeds?

instruction: Can the proposed non-destructive and rapid method based on fusion spectra be used to effectively classify the mildew grade of sunflower seeds, thereby mitigating the risk to human health posed by contaminated seeds?
Output: Yes, the proposed non-destructive and rapid method based on fusion spectra can effectively classify the mildew grade of sunflower seeds. The method combines near-infrared diffuse reflectance and near-infrared diffuse transmission spectra, providing more comprehensive information for better discrimination accuracy. The method utilizes a one-dimension convolutional neural network (1D-CNN) model, which outperformed other conventional machine learning algorithms such as artificial neural network (ANN), support vector machine (SVM), and K-nearest neighbor (KNN).
